title: Boy, 9, charged with murder after house fire kills three toddlers and two adults
text:

A nine-year-old boy has been charged with arson and murder over a house fire that left five people dead.

The boy has been accused of intentionally setting a mobile home in Chicago, Illinois, on fire.

Three children died in the deadly inferno. The youngest was reportedly just one year old.

One-year-old Ariel Wall, her brother Daemeon Wall and cousin Rose Alwood, both aged two; Ariel and Daemeon's father, Jason Wall, 34, and the children's maternal great-grandmother, Kathryn Murray, 69 all died in the inferno.

Two others managed to escape.

The boy faces five counts of first-degree murder, two counts of arson, and one count of aggravated arson over the deadly April fire, the ABC reports.

(Image: Legacy.com)

(Image: Legacy.com)

The controversial decision to charge such a young boy with murder has sent ripples through the American legal community.

One lawyer has argued children young enough to believe in Santa Claus can't form intent to commit murder, according to reports.

Authorities did not say if there was any connection between the suspect and the fire's victims.

Woodford County State’s Attorney Greg Minger told US media "it was a heavy decision" to charge the boy.

He said: "It’s a tragedy, but at the end of the day it’s charging a very young person with one of the most serious crimes we have."

(Image: Legacy.com)

(Image: 25 News)

The prosecutor alleges the fire was set in the knowledge people were at home.

The boy's identity has been withheld, and reports say if he is convicted he will not face jail.

Instead, a conviction would likely lead to mandatory therapy, psychological evaluation, and counselling, Mr Minger said.

But the The Sun reports some lawyers were seriously questioning the decision to charge the boy.

Chicago juvenile defense lawyer Gus Kostopoulos said: "Nine-year-olds don't know that Santa Claus doesn't exist.

"They don't know people die and don't come back to life.

(Image: 25 News)

"I don't know if nine-year-olds can form intent to commit murder."

The Juveline Justice Initiative also criticised the move, calling the charges "completely" out of line" and at odds with what experts know about children's brain development.

The organisation's president Betsy Clark pointed out 14 is the minimum age for criminal prosecution in many countries, including Germany.

In the UK, it is 10, meaning children under that age can't be arrested or charged with a crime, although they can be punished and receive treatment in other ways.

Children aged between 10 and 17 in the UK are dealt with in youth courts, except for in the most extreme cases, such as when 10-year-olds Jon Venables and Robert Thompson were tied as adults for the notorious 1993 murder of two-year-old James Bulger.
description: Two children aged two and a one-year-old died in the inferno in Chicago, along with their dad and great-grandma
